Line.Text: Good morning, Michael. How was your night?
All right, I guess… all things considered.
Better than my day.
How could it be? Sleeping was hardly realistic.
Well, I hope the good tendency continues today. Ready for the next problem?
Well, if it is of any consolation, today’s job shouldn’t be so emotionally taxing… at least that’s what I expect.
Does it mean I get a proper briefing this time?

Actually, I myself just wanted to say a few words. But you get two helpers on the scene today, so any questions you might have will definitely be answered.[clear]Right now, in an apartment not so far from here, there is a young woman who lost her job because of a very unpleasant incident online. She took it bad… bad enough to start having suicidal thoughts.[pause] That incident wouldn’t have happened if it wasn’t for a certain manipulative bully. Your task will be to figure out who that bully was.
What kind of incident?
Having thoughts? Did she call a hotline or something?
Does she even want your help? She didn’t ask for it – she just blogged about her thoughts.
Tell me more about this monitoring system.
How am I supposed to do it?
I see. Is it time to start?
Impersonation. Somebody managed to really damage her relationships with others by pretending to be her online. Our tech specialist will fill you in on why and how exactly that happened.
No, but she blogged about it, and we search for this kind of things.
You search for suicide-related posts?

Yes. We have an automated system that takes all recent public messages, from blogs or otherwise, and analyzes them for keywords, phrasing, speech patterns to determine whether the author might be in any kind of danger, including the danger from heavy depression and suicidal thoughts.[pause] Then it sends us notifications, and we react. Send someone to help.
That’s pretty cool.
Sounds kinda creepy.
What a nice piece of mass surveillance.
Thank you. I certainly feel that this is a good use of our resources.

Why? We don’t violate people’s privacy, or any other right.[pause] The data is already public, posted by its creators for everyone to see – we just sift through it with a specialized algorithm. It’s no different from a search engine, really.

Do you attach a negative connotation to these words? Because we don’t violate people’s privacy or any other rights, you know.[pause] The data is already public, posted by its creators for everyone to see – we just sift through it with a specialized algorithm. It’s no different from a search engine, really.
Well, she didn’t drive us away when we showed up on her doorstep either. I think it’s safe to assume that she wouldn’t mind if we try, at the very least.
If you’re interested, sure.
What about people who don’t leave suicide notes? Or those who leave them but on a simple piece of paper?
What if it’s already too late? Some might do it immediately after leaving a post. Some might even queue their message to post after it is done.
Don’t you worry about false alerts? Arriving just to find someone fooling around?
Do you even have enough computational power? The amount of new data appearing online every single second was staggering even back in my time.
Sounds like a job for the government or a non-profit. Why would a corporation do something like this?
Okay, I get the picture.
Them we can’t help, unfortunately. But a lot of them do, and many choose to be public about it. When you are talking to everyone yet nobody in particular… there’s a strange comfort in that.
Yes, that’s possible, and that happens from time to time. Still, we have to always hope for the best and send someone as quickly as we can.
It’s still worth it. These are people’s lives we are talking about. If it means some resources get wasted along the way, so be it.
We do, that’s what makes it all possible. We’ve been able to wrestle with sheer volume of stuff in this world for quite some time, and that alone led to a number of wonderful things.
Well, we are the best-equipped group for the job… which also makes us responsible to see it through, I think.
It’d be interesting to hear your thoughts on the topic after you finish with the problem. After all, cases like this are the main way to see how effective or ineffective this system is.
Make a little investigation.
Playing detective? I like it.
Won’t you rather get a professional investigator for that?
Another job I am not qualified to do, then.
Well, as long as you take it seriously, feel free to enjoy it.[pause] The guys on the scene will take care of technical stuff; you’ll just have to use your rational thinking and your better judgment.

Don’t worry, the guys on the scene are qualified to take care of occupation-specific stuff; in fact, one of them is a professional investigator.[pause] You’ll just have to use your rational thinking and your better judgment to tie it all together.

Don’t worry, the guys on the scene will take care of occupation-specific stuff; you’ll just have to use your rational thinking and your better judgment.[pause] I did say that every problem will be perfectly solvable by a man of your skills, and I stand by that.
Yeah, everything is ready on our end. Let’s go, I’ll take you downstairs. Your ride is waiting.
Welcome back. Sounds like you’ve managed to solve the case.
I don’t know… I’m not sure if I’ve made the right choice.
Yes, I did. I work better when I’m the one playing mind games, not when they are played on me.
If you say so. Not sure I really care for the whole thing.
Well, I agree with Shawn – you did everything one could expect in this situation.
That’s an interesting comparison with yesterday’s problem. I’m glad you’ve been feeling more comfortable today.
Yeah, that’s fine. You are not required to get excited about every single situation we throw at you.
Welcome back. Sounds like there was more to this story than we initially thought, wasn’t it?
But, naturally, you had no idea about that.
But, naturally, you had no idea it’d turn out like this.
Have you been watching my every step through cameras again?
What happens with the culprit?
What happens with the hacker?
And what about Ashley?
So, does this ends the second problem?
So, does this ends the second problem? Are you satisfied with my work?

Please, you seriously overestimate my powers. I might have prepared a few surprises in other problems, but I can’t pull this stuff out of a hat.[pause] Hacking is indeed a rare occurrence nowadays, let alone impersonation of dozens of different people at once. I was just as surprised as others when it turned into a high-profile hacking case.
Well, I wasn’t. It looked like you guys just ignored a viable explanation, and then it came back to bite you.
Still, you had your own hacker on the scene to track the guy down, and you also had a brute that can apprehend dangerous people. Sounds too convenient.
But that’s exactly why your involvement was so important, right? Free from the same logical fallacy, you looked more closely in the right place, and it worked.
That’s called “being on the safe side.” And of course I’d want you to remain on the safe side; you’re the center of the company’s most important project right now.
No, but Shawn and Kettley told me enough to get the picture.
Kettley as well?
Of course. Personally, I think Kettley’s involvement was much more important. You can probably guess why.
Oh, right. Your “outsider’s perspective” thing.
I’d rather not.
I’m sure you already did, though.
I suppose everyone’s got their quirks.
Sounds like a confirmation bias to me.
I must say though, it’s admirable that you’re not only okay with different opinions but actually want them.
Yeah, I suppose so.
Maybe it is. But what can I do? I’m just a human, and humans are way too good with patterns.
Thank you. That is exactly how I try to approach it.

We’ll try to talk her into confession, but otherwise… nothing. I trust your judgment completely, but we can’t take any serious legal action yet, as there’s no hard evidence.[pause] I guess we’ll need to use more resources and try to rectify it, but that comes later. This week, our project is a clear priority.

We’ll try to talk him into confession, but otherwise… nothing. I trust your judgment completely, but we can’t take any serious legal action yet, as there’s no hard evidence.[pause] I guess we’ll need to use more resources and try to rectify it, but that comes later. This week, our project is a clear priority.
He gets a fair trial and a good lawyer. The charges are serious and, if he is proven guilty, involve several years in prison.
Serves him right.
I think a mental institution might be more appropriate.
Well, he deliberately tried to destroy another person’s mental and financial well-being; there’s no going around that. Would you play it differently?
I mean, there was no lasting damage in the end.
It’s still just the internet. You shouldn’t take it so seriously.
No, not at all. When a person talks this way, something definitely needs to be done.
I think a mental institution might be more appropriate.
I’m really in no position to decide that.
It doesn’t matter. A murder attempt is still a murder attempt, even if a victim survives.

It’s never “just the internet.” It’s been playing a far too important role for too long to be treated as a separate part of our lives anymore.[pause] That was kinda the point of the entire problem… at least I thought this way.
Yeah, that’s one way to put it.
I like how careful you are in your judgments. That’s a good habit.
I mean, he deliberately tried to destroy another person’s mental and financial well-being; there’s no going around that. Do you agree that’s how we should play it?
For sure. When a person talks this way, something definitely needs to be done.
I assume there’s no chance of capital punishment?

You assume correct, even if it was something much more serious. Every person is a product of their environment… we can’t just kill off the malfunctioned parts.[pause] But I’m pushing the scope of our conversation here, sorry.
Oh, they provide pretty good mental help there nowadays. Every serious lawbreaker has something broken inside them and can benefit from a bit of healing.
Yeah, Kettley mentioned that prisons aren’t what they’re used to be.
That sounds like a wise way to handle it… theoretically.
Provided that the healing is adequate, of course.
Must be very convenient to spread conformity under the banner of “healing.”
I’d say that a good thing.
It’s not without problems, of course, but it’s a good step forward compared to the “lock up and forget” policies of the old.
Our doctors and scientists are trying their best. It’s a delicate area, of course, and it’s not without problems, but it’s been getting steadily better for quite some time now.
It’s not as intrusive as it might sound, believe me. They try to convince convicts in the benefits of healing, sure, but they never shove it down their throats.
We will continue to provide her help, just like Shawn said, even if she didn’t really have suicidal thoughts.
Actually, I think she did… she just never acknowledged it to herself.
But it turned out to be a false alarm. Why still spend resources?
And you’re okay with it? She basically manipulated you by making it look more drastic than it was.
Really? And what makes you say that?

She seemed so calm in her defeated state… like she admitted for a fact that she’s a failure and there's nothing to be done about it. I’m no expert, but it looks like a fitting condition to suddenly wave your hand and say goodbye to everything.
I see… well, that makes our involvement even more important. And thank you… for being such an attentive and empathic observer. Seriously.
Because it’s better than stopping halfway through. Suicidal thoughts or not, she was shaken pretty badly by the incident. And mental disturbances don’t disappear the moment their cause is removed.

I wouldn’t call it “manipulation”… taking advantage, perhaps. But like I said to you this morning, it’s still worth it. These are people’s lives we are talking about.[pause] Besides, with this turning into a hacking case, I don’t think anyone can complain it was in vain.

I wouldn’t call it “manipulation”… taking advantage, perhaps. But it’s still worth it. These are people’s lives we are talking about.[pause] Besides, with this turning into a hacking case, I don’t think anyone can complain it was in vain.
I wouldn’t call it “manipulation”… taking advantage, perhaps. But like I said to you this morning, it’s still worth it. These are people’s lives we are talking about.
I wouldn’t call it “manipulation”… taking advantage, perhaps. But it’s still worth it. These are people’s lives we are talking about.

Yes! And I thank you for your work today. However you might feel about it, I honestly think it works, and I’m grateful that you agreed to our offer and made this project a reality.[pause] I do have a last question, though.

Yes! And I thank you for everything you did today. However you might feel about it, I honestly think it works, and I’m grateful that you agreed to our offer and made this project a reality.[pause] I do have a last question, though.
Well, if it's the last one…

You’ve learned that we monitor everything people write online, trying to help those in need, even if they don’t ask to. You’ve seen the biggest corporation in the world launch a full-out investigation because a young girl wrote a sad blog post.[pause] Do you think it’s… right? Should we pay so much attention to people’s psychological conditions?[pause] Can we build a better and happier society this way? Or are we just wasting precious time and resources on insignificant emotions?
There are no insignificant emotions. Every tear is a waterfall.
That’s not something that can have a clear-cut answer, I’m afraid. Helping is good. Telling people how they should feel is bad. The border is blurry.
I believe you are. Modern society is over-pampered, even back in my time. You should allow people to sort their own stuff out. That’s what life is all about.

That’s exactly how I feel as well. Thank you for saying it…[pause] and with this, I think it’s time to wrap up for today. Let’s try to relax for the rest of the evening, and we’ll carry on tomorrow. Have a good night.

Yeah, I suppose you’re right; finding balance is the trickiest part. Thanks for your input…[pause] and with this, I think it’s time to wrap up for today. Let’s try to relax for the rest of the evening, and we’ll carry on tomorrow. Have a good night.
I see…
You don’t agree?

No. But I don’t have all the answers myself, of course. And I also believe that having conflicted opinions may be more beneficial. So thanks for your input…[pause] and with this, I think it’s time to wrap up for today. Let’s try to relax for the rest of the evening, and we’ll carry on tomorrow. Have a good night.
